p: At laboratory diagnosis, the virus neutralization test (VNT) is generally used to detect rising titers of neutralization antibody in paired acute and convalescent sera from affected cattle which show the typical clinical signs of BEF ( 14). For serological detection of BEFV, an indirect-ELISA with the recombinant protein of BEFV G gene was also developed ( 31). In recent years, conventional RT-PCRs targeting the G gene was available to detect BEFV in the diseased cattle ( 32â€“ 34). Real-time RT-PCR and reverse-transcription, loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) assays were also established for rapid and sensitive detection of BEFV gene ( 32, 35, 36).
